author: ikarstein
body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

Create a Runspace.  `using (Runspace myRunSpace = RunspaceFactory.CreateRunspace(host))`

Create a PowerShell object: `using (System.Management.Automation.PowerShell powershell = System.Management.Automation.PowerShell.Create())`

Add a script file: `powershell.AddScript("& C:\SOURCE\MYSCRIPT.PS1", true);`

Execute... `powershell.BeginInvoke<PSObject, PSObject>`



### Expected behavior

```console
Executed without errors as with Windows PowerShell 5.1. This is still working with the same code and script.
```


### Actual behavior

```console
I get this exception

`File C:\SOURCE\MYSCRIPT.PS1 cannot be loaded because running scripts is disabled on this system. For more information, see about_Execution_Policies at https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=135170.
```


### Error details

_No response_


comments.body: Yes. I did. But I want to use Powershell 7.2 inside a .net 6.0 console application. For Powershell 5.1 I found a workaround using class RunspaceInvoke. - I wonder there is a solution with Powershell 7.2 too.

comments.body: Why don't you set the policy in (ex.) RemoteSigned in any of the ways described?
